summary: Students take notes during a lesson at the Global Indian International School in Tokyo. (Photo by Natsumi Kawasaki) School costs are around half the level of Western-oriented schools NATSUMI...
title: Japanese flock to Indian international schools in Tokyo on lower tuition

content:
Billionaire's Grok-3 AI model competes with China's DeepSeek and Microsoft's OpenAI

(Reuters) — Elon Musk’s xAI artificial intelligence company has acquired Musk’s X social media platform for $33 billion, marking the latest twist in the billionaire’s rapid consolidation of power.

The all-stock deal announced on Friday combines two of Musk’s multiple companies, which include automaker Tesla and SpaceX, and potentially eases Musk’s ability to train his Grok AI model.

Musk announced the transaction in a post on his social media platform, originally known as Twitter, “The combination values xAI at $80 billion and X at $33 billion ($45B less $12B debt).”

“xAI and X’s futures are intertwined,” he wrote. “Today, we officially take the step to combine the data, models, compute, distribution and talent.”

Neither X nor xAI spokespersons immediately responded to requests for comment. Much of the deal’s specifics remained unclear, such as how investors might be compensated, how X’s leaders would be integrated, or the prospect of regulatory scrutiny.

“This development feels surprising and somewhat unexpected,” PP Foresight analyst Paolo Pescatore said. “To a certain extent, it closes a chapter in the turbulent saga of X.”

“The choice of $45 billion is not a coincidence,” said D.A. Davidson & Co. analyst Gil Luria. “It is $1 billion higher than the take-private transaction for Twitter in 2022” and he can share the value of the xAI business with Twitter co-investors.

Musk, the world’s wealthiest man, has also consolidated his power in Washington by overseeing the Trump administration’s cost-cutting efforts as head of the so-called Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE). That has also put him in a position to potentially influence agencies that oversee his business dealings.

An investor in xAI, and now in the combined entity, told Reuters they were not surprised by the deal, viewing it as Musk consolidating his leadership and management at his own companies. The investor declined to be named.

Musk did not ask investors for approval but told them that the two companies had been collaborating closely and the integration would drive deeper integration with Grok.

Musk’s xAI startup was launched less than two years ago and recently raised $10 billion in a funding round that valued the company at $75 billion, according to a media report.

In February, Musk, 53, made a $97.4 billion bid with a consortium for the ChatGPT maker OpenAI, which was rejected, with OpenAI saying that the startup was not for sale. Musk co-founded OpenAI with CEO Sam Altman in 2015.

Musk competes directly with the popular OpenAI platform and has sued in federal court in California to prevent his rival from converting from a non-profit to a for-profit business. A judge earlier this month denied Musk’s request for a preliminary injunction that would prevent the changeover.

The wide release of AI software has set off a flurry of investment and competition in Silicon Valley. To be more efficient companies are seeking ways to integrate the software into nearly every part of their operations.

As competition in AI intensifies, xAI has been ramping up its data center capacity to train more advanced models. Its supercomputer cluster in Memphis, Tennessee, called “Colossus,” is touted as the largest in the world.

xAI introduced Grok-3, the latest iteration of its chatbot, in February, as it takes on China’s DeepSeek and Microsoft-backed OpenAI. The X platform can serve to further distribute xAI products, while also providing a real-time feed of users’ musings, screenshots and other data.

Musk clinched a deal in 2022 to buy Twitter for $44 billion, ending its run as a public company since its 2013 initial public offering, declaring that “the bird is freed” once the acquisition closed.

He gutted the company’s workforce after the acquisition, prompting advertisers to flee the platform and a rapid decline in revenue. Recently, brands have been returning to X as Musk’s influence grows in the Trump administration.

The seven banks that extended $13 billion in loans to Musk to buy X kept the debt on their books for two years until they could sell it all at once last month, according to a source familiar with the transactions.

This was made possible after a surge in investor interest for exposure to AI companies along with X’s improved operating performance over the previous two quarters, among other factors, according to two people familiar with the matter.

After the merger, investors who bought the debt from the banks will profit, said Espen Robak, founder of Pluris Valuation Advisors, which specializes in illiquid assets. “For sure the debt is worth more now, if not fully paid off.”

Separately, a U.S. judge on Friday rejected a bid by Musk to dismiss a lawsuit claiming he had defrauded former Twitter shareholders by waiting too long to disclose his initial investment in the company.
summary: Elon Musk announced the all-stock deal on March 28, saying the combined entity would be valued at $80 billion. © Reuters Billionaire's Grok-3 AI model competes with China's DeepSeek and Microsoft's Op...
title: Elon Musk’s xAI buys Musk’s X social media platform for $33bn

content:
Fujiya Hotel, host to Charlie Chaplin and John Lennon, finds snowy days are a big hit

YOKOHAMA, Japan — After a hiatus of 10 years, long-time hospitality business specialist Akira Ando last June returned to the post of president at the operator of the Fujiya Hotel, Japan’s first genuine resort hotel, in the town of Hakone, Kanagawa Prefecture.

The inn’s 500-year history pivoted in 1877 when industrialist Sennosuke Yamaguchi bought the Fujiya Ryokan, rebuilt it and a year later reopened it as the Fujiya Hotel, catering to foreign visitors.

Through the decades, it has hosted many foreign celebrities. The likes of Charlie Chaplin and Helen Keller visited in the prewar era, while John Lennon and his wife, Yoko Ono, stayed in the postwar period.

At the end of World War II, the property was confiscated by the Allied forces, who returned it in 1954 when it resumed normal business operations.

Nikkei interviewed Ando about the classic hotel’s role in Japan’s current inbound tourism boom. Edited excerpts from the interview follow.

Q: You have returned to the presidency of Fujiya Hotel after serving as president of Hanamaki Onsen in Iwate Prefecture for 10 years. How do you analyze the current tourism situation in Hakone?

A: After the Japan Tourism Agency was founded in 2008, attracting inbound tourists became a government imperative. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the number of visitors to Japan totaled a record high of 36.86 million in 2024. They spent 8.1 trillion yen ($53.79 billion), up a sharp 53% from 5.3 trillion yen in 2023.

The Fujiya Hotel was closed in 2018 for anti-seismic reinforcements and large-scale renovations, resuming operations in July 2020. (Photo by Kohga Takeuchi)

Hakone is readily accessible from both Narita and Haneda airports. Odawara Station on the Shinkansen bullet train line offers good access, while Odakyu Electric Railway’s Romancecar limited express train is also convenient. Hakone is full of attractions for inbound tourists, including … the Hakone Ropeway and the sightseeing cruise on Lake Ashi (Ashinoko).

Q: What is the role of your 147-year-old classic hotel?

A: A large number of luxury hotels, including foreign hotels, are planning to operate in the Hakone area. There will be many in a higher price range than the Fujiya Hotel. We must offer services that enable guests to feel history and culture and that cannot be copied by new hotels.

Classic hotels exist in Karuizawa, Nikko, Yokohama and other places, and I believe they serve as local people’s mental anchor. In addition to the attractiveness of our buildings, designated as nationally registered tangible cultural properties, we will walk the royal road in which employees learn the history and culture of Hakone and thoroughly serve guests in a manner that pays great attention to detail.

Q: Japanese have a deep admiration (for the Fujiya Hotel). How do foreign tourists see it?

A: As China and Europe have long histories, our hotel is not so appealing to people there even if we stress that it was built in the Meiji era (1868-1912). Although French and other Western cuisines are our symbol, visitors from abroad want to eat Japanese meals. While we offer Japanese cuisine at the Kikka-So, a former imperial residence, we have also added Japanese elements to our Western meals.

Akira Ando returned as president of the Fujiya Hotel’s operator in June 2024, after a 10-year hiatus. (Photo by Kohga Takeuchi)

Although Mount Fuji cannot be observed from our hotel, Hakone has many locations that offer such vistas. Guests from Southeast Asia and Taiwan are so pleased when they see snow. They are surprised at the vibrant colors of tree leaves during the fall foliage season. Our many Instagrammable spots are an attraction.

Visitors from abroad accounted for 23% of Fujiya Hotel guests in fiscal 2023. We expect a ratio of 28% or so in fiscal 2024. I’ve heard there are hotels with an inbound guest ratio of nearly 80% in Tokyo. As we hope to raise our figure to 50% in the future, we need to carry out programs to increase inbound guests on weekdays and during low tourism seasons.

Q: What are you going to do to contribute to the further development of the Hakone area?

A: Public and private collaboration is a must for the overseas dissemination of information and public relations activities abroad. Reactions differ if you campaign for tourists abroad as a private group or with government officials. We will also work together with tourism industry officials in Kamakura, Yokohama and other places in a bid to prevent Kanagawa Prefecture from becoming solely a destination of same-day round trips from Tokyo.

When we showed officials of a South Korean travel agency around, they said, as I was told later, that they wanted to play golf at various courses. There are many golf courses around Hakone, and they can be sources for three- to four-day stays. There also are many mountains good for trekking. Mount Kintoki is known for its association with the legend of the folk hero Kintaro (a boy with superhuman strength who was raised by his “mountain witch” mother). We will propose experimental travel like basking in hot springs.
summary: Among Japanese, the Fujiya Hotel, which took its name in 1878, is known as the country's first genuine resort hotel. (Photo by Kohga Takeuchi) Fujiya Hotel, host to Charlie Chaplin and John Lenno...
title: Classic Japan hotel lures guests with seasonal Instagrammability

content:
Some see his arrest as a calculated move to cast himself as a tragic hero

TOKYO — Clad in a simple blue suit during his initial hearing at the International Criminal Court (ICC) on March 14, former Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte showed little of the commanding presence he once displayed as a strongman leader.

Participating in the pre-trial proceedings in The Hague, Netherlands, via video link from a detention center about 2 kilometers away, Duterte spoke softly and haltingly in English, providing his name, date of birth and place of origin.

At the seaside detention facility, often called the “Hague Hilton” for its relatively humane conditions, Duterte marked his 80th birthday on March 28. He is the first former national leader from Asia to be held at the high-security unit, which also houses five other inmates, including former Kosovo President Hashim Thaci, who faces war crime charges.

Three days before his court appearance, Duterte was arrested by Philippine police upon arriving at Manila’s airport from Hong Kong and was subsequently transferred to The Hague. He faces accusations of “crimes against humanity” for allegedly directing police and private death squads to kill at least 43 suspected drug offenders and others between 2011 and 2019, including during his time as mayor of the city of Davao before becoming president of the Philippines in 2016.

Late last year, a joint committee of the Philippine House of Representatives concluded that more than 30,000 people were killed in a wave of extrajudicial executions during the Duterte administration’s brutal war on drugs. The committee recommended prosecuting the former president within the Philippine judicial system, but ultimately, the case was referred to international authorities — an extraordinary step for a country not involved in armed conflict.

Supporters of Duterte gather for a prayer rally in Manila on March 15.   © Reuters

The ICC, a United Nations-backed court of last resort, prosecutes individuals for grave crimes when national courts are unwilling or unable to do so. It is currently presided over by Japanese judge Tomoko Akane. In recent months, the ICC has issued arrest warrants for Russian President Vladimir Putin over the abduction of children from occupied Ukraine, and for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for attacks on civilians in Gaza. Both face charges of war crimes. However, the enforcement of these warrants relies heavily on the cooperation of the countries involved or those that are signatories to the court’s founding treaty, the Rome Statute.

In Duterte’s case, the ICC launched a preliminary investigation in 2018 after receiving complaints from victims’ families. However, Duterte removed the Philippines from the court’s jurisdiction the next year, and his successor, President Ferdinand Marcos Jr., appeared unwilling to cooperate. This raises the question of what prompted the sudden arrest this time. The ICC asserts that it retains jurisdiction over crimes committed before the country’s withdrawal, while the Marcos administration argues that it could not ignore a formal request for cooperation received through Interpol.

Behind this seemingly smooth coordination lies a deeper power struggle between two former allies: the Marcos and Duterte dynasties.

In the 2022 presidential election, Duterte’s daughter, Sara, who was then mayor of Davao, led early opinion polls. However, in a surprising turn of events, she withdrew from the race and announced her candidacy for vice president, forming a joint ticket with Marcos, who was already running for president. With her support, Marcos surged from second place to win in a landslide.

Some observers speculated that Sara stepped aside despite her near-certain win to avoid political interference from her father. In fact, Rodrigo Duterte was reportedly outraged by what he saw as Sara’s “defeat by default.” Nevertheless, with the Philippine constitution limiting presidents to a single six-year term with no possibility of re-election, Sara remains eligible for a future run. For Rodrigo Duterte, the alliance may have been a strategic move to avoid potential prosecution after leaving office.

Marcos, for his part, likely would not have become president without Sara making way. He also owed a political debt to her father: During Duterte’s presidency, he allowed the burial of Ferdinand Marcos Sr., Marcos’ father and former dictator, at the cemetery for national heroes, a move that sparked outrage among human rights groups. The unspoken agreement was that Marcos would not cooperate with the ICC and, after six years, would support Sara’s bid for the presidency.

Philippine Vice President Sara Duterte, left, raises the arm of newly elected President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. during his inauguration ceremony in Manila in June 2022.    © Reuters

But not everyone in the Marcos camp was happy with this arrangement. Chief among the dissenters was House Speaker Martin Romualdez, a close ally and maternal cousin of Marcos. A media magnate who controls a broad portfolio of newspapers and broadcast stations, Romualdez “is powerful and has control over the majority of the members of Congress — through patronage politics,” according to Marites Danguilan Vitug, editor at large of the Manila-based online news outlet Rappler.

Vitug told Nikkei Asia that Romualdez also has “aspirations to run for president in 2028.”

The lower house scrutinized Sara — who was also serving as education secretary — for alleged misuse of government funds, removing discretionary funds from both the Office of the Vice President and the Department of Education in the fiscal 2024 budget. Romualdez is also said to have led a proposal for a constitutional amendment, ostensibly aimed at encouraging greater foreign investment. However, the move drew Rodrigo Duterte’s ire after Marcos hinted at the possibility of revising its provisions, including term limits for public office.

Rodrigo Duterte accused Marcos of attempting to lift term limits and held a protest rally in his hometown of Davao at the end of January 2024. “You (Marcos) might end up like your father,” Duterte said at the rally, which was also attended by Sara. “That’s what I’m afraid might happen to you.”

Since then, relations between the two families have quickly deteriorated. In July, Sara resigned as education secretary without explanation and skipped the president’s annual State of the Nation Address. In October, Marcos expressed his disillusionment with Sara, stating that he had considered her a friend but may have been “deceived.” In response, Sara remarked that she had “never been friends with him to begin with.”

Tensions further escalated when Sara threatened to exhume the remains of Marcos Sr. and dispose of them at sea. “I will get the body of your father and throw it in the West Philippine Sea,” she said.

In November, Rodrigo Duterte made a significant “slip of the tongue” during a joint congressional committee investigation into the war on drugs, providing grounds for his potential arrest. “I’m asking the ICC to hurry up, and if possible, they can come here and start the investigation tomorrow,” he said at the inquiry.

Sara made an even more shocking statement, claiming she had contracted an assassin to kill President Marcos, his wife and the house speaker if she were to be killed herself. Her comment sparked a firestorm of controversy. Seizing on the opportunity, the lower house passed an impeachment complaint against her in February with a majority vote. The trial is scheduled to take place in the Senate in June or later, after Congress resumes following the midterm elections in May.

Philippine House Speaker Martin Romualdez, right, welcomes then-Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida at a joint session of Congress in Quezon, Philippines, in November 2023.   © Reuters

Initially, Marcos hesitated to offer cooperation to the ICC or push for Sara’s impeachment, possibly concerned about breaching their “tacit agreement.” However, as the situation intensified, he seems to have decided to eliminate his political rivals.

But the Dutertes are not standing idly by.

As the previous election showed, father and daughter do not always move in lockstep. While both are known for their fiery temperaments, there is a key distinction: Unlike the impulsive and quick-tempered Sara, her father is a seasoned, calculating politician whose primary concern has always been self-preservation. So, why did he take action to provoke the ICC and the Marcos administration?

The answer may lie in a two-minute video message Duterte recorded in both English and Tagalog for his supporters while being transported to The Hague. He later shared it on social media.

“Whatever happened in the past, I will be the front of our law enforcement and the military,” Duterte said in the message. “I said this already, that I will protect you, and I will be responsible for everything.”

“This will be a long legal proceeding, but I say to you, I will continue to serve my country. And so be it, if that is my destiny,” he added.

Wataru Kusaka, a professor at Tokyo University of Foreign Studies, sees Duterte’s actions as carefully calculated, well attuned to exploiting the cultural dynamics of the sole Asian country in which Christianity is the national religion.

“Narratives of suffering, death and resurrection resonate strongly with the people of the Philippines,” he said. “In films and dramas, the most popular characters are often martyrs, and Duterte is deliberately playing the role of someone who endures suffering to save the public.”

Both the Marcos and Duterte camps are thus attempting to leverage international justice for political gain, tapping into a powerful narrative of martyrdom — one that runs deep in the country’s modern political history.

One of the most prominent examples is that of the late Sen. Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino Jr., who returned to the Philippines from exile in the U.S. in 1983, fully aware of the danger he would face under the Marcos Sr. dictatorship. He was assassinated upon arrival, but his wife, Corazon Aquino, led the 1986 People Power Revolution that overthrew the Marcos regime and went on to become president. Their eldest son, Benigno “Noynoy” Aquino III, later followed in her footsteps to become a national leader.

Another case in point is Joseph “Erap” Estrada, a popular film star who capitalized on his image as a rugged justice-seeking outlaw. Running on a populist platform with the slogan “Erap for the Poor,” he won the presidency in 1998. Although he was later forced to resign amid corruption charges, Estrada made a political comeback by winning election as mayor of Manila in 2013.

Ferdinand Marcos Sr., seated next to his wife Imelda, speaks at Hickam Air Force Base in Honolulu, Hawaii, in February 1986, after being deposed as president in the People Power Revolution.    © AP

The Marcos family is no stranger to this tradition. In the presidential election three years ago, Marcos Jr. skillfully leveraged social media, spreading misinformation that downplayed the human rights abuses during his father’s regime and claimed strong economic growth that never actually materialized. The campaign successfully reframed his father as a tragic figure driven into exile by his rivals, a narrative that helped the family reclaim the presidency after 36 years.

Fully aware of the power of the martyrdom narrative, Marcos — now nearing the midpoint of his term — has made a calculated move to marginalize the Duterte faction, which is trying to harness that same power for its own survival.

All eyes are now on the upcoming midterm elections in May, particularly the Senate race. Of the 24 seats, half are up for grabs, and the newly elected senators will play a crucial role in Sara’s impeachment trial. If two-thirds — at least 16 senators — vote to convict her, she will be removed from office and barred from holding any future public post.

If that happens, the Duterte camp will lose its strongest contender for the next presidential race. But if Sara survives, a dynastic showdown with Romualdez becomes increasingly likely. As a result, a fierce contest for control of the Senate is all but certain.

“Duterte’s arrest may influence voter sentiment and political dynamics. However, the arrest highlights the issues of accountability, impunity, and the rule of law, which also sway public opinion, impact the electoral landscape by shifting voter priorities and perceptions, and affect the popularity and even the credibility of candidates associated with Duterte,” Victor Manhit, president of the Philippine think tank Stratbase, said in comments to Nikkei.

“The most he can do is instigate misguided activism and loyalty among his supporters,” Manhit said. “Our latest analysis projects that the presidential camp is most likely to secure a two-thirds majority of the Senate, which is necessary to convict the vice president.”

Still, it is important to note that Duterte maintained remarkably high approval ratings until the very end of his term, despite his widely known campaign of extrajudicial killings. This enduring popularity was driven by the public’s yearning for a “strong leader” and an effective approach to law and order.

How this public sentiment will unfold remains uncertain. Given that the rule of law does not always prevail in the Philippines, the second act of “Duterte theater” could be full of surprises.
summary: Former Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte appears on a screen at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, Netherlands, on March 14. © Reuters Some see his arrest as a calculated move to cast h...
title: ‘Martyr’ Duterte seeks to capture the hearts of the Philippine public

content:
Japanese sci-fi franchise's owner Bandai Namco to triple model kit shops in China

TOKYO — More than 45 years after the sci-fi anime series “Gundam” debuted on TV in Japan, entertainment group Bandai Namco Holdings will tap related intellectual property for further growth, making a live-action Hollywood movie to introduce the fighting robots to a wider audience abroad.

The company will also boost production capacity for the franchise’s core products — model kits — with a whole new factory in Japan to address tight supplies, while increasing the network of stores dedicated to such kits in China.

Bandai Namco surprised fans in February when it announced a partnership with Legendary Pictures — the Hollywood studio behind such hits as the “Dune” franchise — for a live-action adaptation of the Gundam series. It was a long-awaited update on the project, which was first unveiled in 2018.

The U.S. has been a difficult market to grow. “For visual works, overseas markets account for only about 30% of total revenue,” said Naohiro Ogata, who oversees the production of Gundam animations. “Compared to how popular the Gundam franchise is in China and other parts of Asia, it is not well-known in Europe and the U.S.”

Only one Gundam series has aired with all episodes in North America. Airing in 2000, the opportunities to watch that series were limited until streaming platforms became available.

Bandai Namco intends to handle the North American distribution of the live-action movie on its own so it can also offer more non-live-action movies as well, leveraging its experience of distribution in Japan. With group companies around the world selling toys and games, Ogata said that expanding in-house distribution would allow Bandai Namco to piggyback on the movies to promote those products.

Gundam is one of Japan’s most famous long-running intellectual properties, with the original “Mobile Suit Gundam” airing in April 1979. It did not have high ratings initially but became a smash hit through reruns and the release of plastic model kits of the giant robots, known as “Gunpla.”

The anime’s focus on wartime human drama that goes beyond a good-versus-evil theme has also received plaudits. The franchise has continued to release new anime and movies, boasting more than 70 titles in its library.

“The series has continued with different protagonists, so each generation in different markets has a special attachment to their ‘first Gundam.’ That’s one of the franchise’s key strengths,” said Hiroshi Sakakibara, president of Bandai Spirits, the core unit for model kits. Sakakibara is also the chief Gundam officer at the parent company.

The franchise’s growth is driven by anime works and model kits. Sales of Gundam merchandise at Bandai Namco is expected to reach 148 billion yen ($983 million) for the year ending March 31, doubling over the past decade. The series is the second-highest grossing franchise at the parent behind the “Dragon Ball” franchise, which is set to bring in 180 billion yen.

The Gundam franchise’s longevity is thanks to the substantial freedom afforded by the ownership of intellectual properties. While Bandai Namco has achieved success with products based on such manga comic series as “Dragon Ball” and “One Piece,” they are licensed by major publisher Shueisha, with the original creators and rights holders having a say over a wide range of matters.

A giant ‘Gundam’ statue will greet visitors to the Gundam Next Future Pavilion at Osaka Expo, set to open in April. (Photo by Hiromasa Matsuura)

With Gundam, the Bandai Namco group holds all the rights, affording it significant creative liberties. “We can change the original vision and universe because our group owns the rights,” said Ogata. “It also allows us to quickly expand the series outside of anime.”

The model kits generate strong sales worldwide. Coming with complex designs and transformation mechanisms, the models also bring to life the colors shown in anime without the use of paint, thanks to high-quality, multicolor molding technology.

Overseas markets account for half of total sales. The product lineup ranges from beginner kits sold for around 500 yen to upmarket models priced at 50,000 yen. About 5,000 different models have hit the market to date since the 1980 launch.

In China, Bandai Namco runs seven shops dedicated to Gundam model kits in cities including Shanghai. The group plans to set up shop in Hubei province’s Wuhan and other inland cities to bring the total to 20 by 2027.

The group is also planning a new trading card game combining figures and cards for a domestic release in July and an international launch in 2026.

One challenge in merchandise is that the supply of model kits has been outpaced by global demand. In Japan, the shortage enabled resellers who bought Gundam model kits in bulk to sell at exorbitant prices.

A new factory is set to come online in Shizuoka prefecture this summer, lifting the group’s production capacity by 35%. But it is unclear whether this will resolve the supply shortage. The group also needs to train enough technicians with required skills.

“Bandai Namco uses special injection molding machines and it apparently takes time to adjust them when they are installed,” said Hideki Yasuda, senior analyst at Toyo Securities. One concern is that “if the supply of model kits cannot keep up with demand, fans will not be happy and might lose passion for the series,” he said.
summary: Intricately designed model kits serve as a driving force behind the sustained growth of the 'Gundam' franchise. (Photo by Kanon Wakabayashi) Japanese sci-fi franchise's owner Bandai Namco to triple mo...
title: Gundam franchise gears up for global outreach with live-action movie

content:
Gyeongju combines marvelous blooms with historic tombs and palaces

GYEONGJU, South Korea — In early April last year, I went to South Korea in search of cherry blossoms, and I found them in abundance in Gyeongju, in the southeastern corner of the country, which was wearing a thick coat of white and pink to celebrate this most glorious of seasons.

Japan is well known internationally for its sakura (cherry blossom) season, which attracts eager tourists from all over the world, as well as locals who dress up for hanami — the Japanese tradition of getting together to admire these ephemeral blooms and celebrate the change of season.

But here’s the thing: Not only was traveling to, and in, South Korea cheaper than Japan, but there were times when I had rows of cherry blossom trees all to myself. Most tourists tend to visit Gyeongju as a whistlestop day trip from the larger city of Busan, just an hour’s drive away, but I am glad I decided to spend a couple of nights there, giving it the time and attention it deserves.

As in Japan, South Korea’s cherry blossoms begin to bloom in the south, usually in the last week of March (and even a week earlier on Jeju Island), slowly making their way north to Seoul in early April. By the time I fetched up at Gyeongju after a few days of palace-hopping and shopping in Seoul, I half-expected the flowers to have withered. But to my utter delight, I found the city awash with cherry blossoms.

As well as viewing spots popularized by selfie-seekers I stumbled upon an entire road — Heungmu-ro, I discovered later — lined with trees in full bloom. Such serendipitous discoveries really are the best part of travel. The trees stretched for kilometers along this road, forming a perfect canopy of feathery blooms, under which I walked, stopping for photographs every few feet.

Heungmu-ro, with its flowering trees lining the road for kilometers, is one of Gyeongju’s best spots to bask in blossoms.

I admit that I got quite carried away by the spectacle, dreamily stepping onto the road more than once for that perfect photographic angle. Drivers were extremely considerate, slowing down and waiting patiently until I moved back to the pavement, no longer a danger to their cars or to myself. Perhaps they were just resigned to oblivious tourists in the blossom season.

This walk was by far my favorite experience — my personal hanami. But even outside the short cherry blossom season, Gyeongju is worth a visit. For this charming town comes with a rich dose of history and culture, and five distinct historic areas inscribed together as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, with tombs and monuments, palaces and parks. Gyeongju was the capital of Korea’s Silla dynasty from 57 B.C. to 935 A.D. and the city is now popularly referred to as a “museum without walls.”

While parts of large South Korean cities like Seoul and Busan have fallen prey to modernization, Gyeongju has clung tenaciously to its rich heritage. By law, buildings in the core historic area must be built in traditional hanok style — with a single story and sloping roofs — which dates to the 14th century. It was quite delightful to walk along the roads and look upon global brands such as Starbucks housed in elegant hanoks cheek by jowl with local cafes.

Even modern brands like Starbucks are housed in traditional hanok-style buildings in Gyeongju.

Sated by the cherry blossom chase, I ventured toward more conventional sightseeing, starting with the Tumuli-gongwon, also called the Daereungwon Tomb Complex, in the center of town. Containing 23 ancient tombs of Silla kings, these burial monuments look like grassy mounds that have sprouted up from the earth; the higher the mound, the more influential the person buried underneath.

Archaeological digs have thrown up fascinating artifacts such as gold and jade jewelry, weapons and pottery. But the finds are on display at the Gyeongju National Museum, with only a few replicas inside the tombs. It was a breezy and beautiful afternoon and having no desire to be cooped up inside a burial mound, I preferred to walk around the expansive grounds, which were carpeted with pink azaleas and purple lupins (not to mention the ubiquitous cherry blossoms).

With its mix of modern and ancient architecture, Gyeongju is often referred to as a “museum without walls.”

My aimless amble took me to the Cheomseongdae Observatory, the oldest in Asia, constructed in the mid-first century. It looks like a haphazard pile of stones, but 2,000 years ago observers here were sufficiently sophisticated to plot the night skies and predict weather patterns. The base is formed by 12 stones, one for each month of the year, and the building has 30 vertical layers, symbolizing the days of the month. Exactly 366 stones were used in construction — the number of days in a leap year.

As the evening wore on, I made several photographic pit stops, eventually fetching up at the grounds of the Donggung Palace, another calm oasis amid the urban chaos. I walked through the grounds to the Wolji Pond, a human-made lake that captures near-perfect reflections of the ornate pavilions all around. As dusk fell and the palace lights came on, a gasp went around the waiting crowd as the reflections magically turned golden. Fittingly, the word wolji means “pond that reflects the moon.”

Evening reflections on Wolji Pond at the Donggung Palace complex.

Next morning, an hour’s drive outside town took me to a couple of sites which the combined UNESCO World Heritage listing describes as a “religious architectural complex of exceptional significance.” The Seokguram grotto, with its magnificent Buddha statue from the eighth century, is still held sacred by South Korean Buddhists, who often walk there to offer prayers. Even an agnostic foreigner like me could not remain unmoved by the serenity of the setting, high up on Mount Toham and surrounded by lush forest.

From there, I hiked down a couple of kilometers on a forest path to my next destination — the impressive Buddhist temple of Bulguk-sa. The temple complex contains numerous stone and wood bridges, pagodas, prayer halls and shrines, and was built at the height of the Silla era, reflecting the might and piety of the ancient dynasty.

Top: Visitors at the Bulguk-sa Buddhist temple complex, which has multiple pavilions and pagodas. Bottom: In bloom in Gyeongju.

Gyeongju may radiate history at every turn, but it is far from being stuck in the past. A popular travel website has anointed it South Korea’s newest city of cool, and nowhere is this exemplified more than at Hwangnidan Street with its hanok-based coffee shops and cafes, boutique stores and craft studios, and hanbok (traditional Korean clothing) rental stores that come with photo booths where tourists can have themselves and their costumes immortalized on camera.

This street was filled with young locals, making cute faces for their phone cameras and tucking into slices of pepperoni pizza, not 100 meters from centuries-old tombs and monuments. For me, the scene encompassed the essence of modern-day Gyeongju.

The Seokguram grotto is home to a magnificent eighth-century statue of the Buddha.

Accommodation: Try a unique hanok stay at Siwoowadang Hotel or Yettle Stay for a taste of South Korean tradition. The PBr7 Hotel Unusual Stay lives up to its name — each room containing distinct features such as tatami mats and hot tubs.

Travel: The nearest international airports are at Seoul and Busan, from where Gyeongju is just over two hours or 35 minutes, respectively, by fast train.

Tip: Cherry blossom season forecasts are available on the Visit Korea website from early March.

Charukesi Ramadurai is a contributing writer.
summary: Another picture-postcard view in Gyeongju, South Korea, during cherry blossom season. (All photos by Charukesi Ramadurai) Gyeongju combines marvelous blooms with historic tombs and palaces CHARUKESI R...
title: Cherry blossoms on your mind? Try South Korea

content:
Vice president downplays military force, but says island should fall under American security umbrella

WASHINGTON — U.S. Vice President JD Vance spent three hours in Greenland on Friday, visiting a U.S. Space Force base and channeling the Trump administration’s desire to take a “significant position” in the world’s biggest island.

The first U.S. vice president to visit Greenland, Vance landed at the Pituffik Space Base, some 1,500 kilometers from the North Pole, with his wife Usha Vance, national security adviser Mike Waltz and Energy Secretary Chris Wright. He had lunch with U.S. troops, received a briefing on Arctic security and addressed the service members.

Denmark, to which Greenland belongs, has not done its job in keeping the island safe, the vice president argued, repeatedly saying that Copenhagen has “under-invested” in the kind of infrastructure needed to keep the region safe.

“What is the alternative to give up the North Atlantic, to give up the Arctic to China, to Russia and to other regimes that don’t have the best interest of the American people at heart?” he said.

“We have no other option. We need to take a significant position in Greenland to keep the people here safe.”

He said his pitch to the people of Greenland is that they would be better off under Washington’s “security umbrella” than they have been under Denmark’s.

For decades, NATO member Denmark has spent less than 2% of its gross domestic product on defense. Recent measures to bolster defense spending are to increase that figure to 3% of GDP for 2025 and 2026, the government says.

Before Vance’s visit, Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen told reporters that “unacceptable pressure” was being placed on Greenland and Denmark. “It is pressure that we will resist,” she said.

Greenland Prime Minister Mute Egede described the trip as “highly aggressive” in an interview with a local newspaper, asking, “What is the national security adviser doing in Greenland? The only purpose is to demonstrate power over us.”

Pituffik Space Base. The U.S. has had a military presence in Greenland for decades. (Ritzau Scanpix/Thomas Traasdahl via Reuters)

The original plan was for Usha Vance, one of her sons and Waltz to make a three-day visit to Greenland with stops at historical sites and learn about Greenlandic heritage.

They were to attend the Avannaata Qimussersu, Greenland’s national dogsled race, in the island’s central western city of Sisimiut.

“The race brings together approximately 37 mushers and 444 dogs in a remarkable display of speed, skill, and teamwork. Ms. Vance and the delegation are excited to witness this monumental race and celebrate Greenlandic culture and unity,” her office had said in a press release.

The White House changed the nature of the trip, adding the vice president to the delegation and replacing all visits to historical sites with a visit to the base in the northwestern part of the island. At the base, Vance attempted to clarify the intentions of U.S. President Donald Trump, who has only spoken about Greenland in broad strokes.

At the White House on Friday, Trump said, “We need Greenland.”

Arguing that the island is important for international security, the president said, “It’s not a question of, ‘Do you think we can do without it?’ We can’t.”

Vance said Russia and China are taking “an extraordinary interest” in Arctic passageways, Arctic naval routes and in the minerals of the Arctic territories, without offering any evidence of what he called Chinese efforts to “exploit” the island’s resources.

To counter such actions, Vance said the U.S. will be looking to have a greater military presence in Greenland, giving examples such as additional military icebreakers and naval ships.

But he downplayed the idea of taking Greenland by force.

“We do not think that military force is ever going to be necessary,” he said.

More likely is for the two sides to cut a “Donald Trump style” deal to ensure the security of the territory, the vice president said.
summary: U.S. Vice President JD Vance tours the U.S. military's Pituffik Space Base in Greenland on March 28. (Pool via Reuters)  Vice president downplays military force, but says island should fall under...
title: U.S. needs ‘significant position’ in Greenland to counter China: JD Vance

content:
Consumer spending rebounds less than expected, while price gauge rises

(Reuters) — Wall Street stocks ended sharply lower on Friday, with sell-offs in Amazon, Microsoft and other technology heavyweights, after U.S. data stoked fears of weak economic growth and high inflation as the Trump administration ratchets up tariffs.

U.S. consumer spending rebounded less than expected in February, while a measure of underlying prices increased the most in 13 months.

Adding to concerns, a University of Michigan survey showed consumers’ 12-month inflation expectations soared to the highest in nearly two and a half years in March and they expect inflation to remain elevated beyond the next year.

That data fueled fears that a rush of tariff announcements from U.S. President Donald Trump since taking office in January will boost prices of imported goods, drive inflation and deter the Federal Reserve from cutting interest rates.

Inflation and tariff worries sent shares of Wall Street’s most valuable companies sharply lower, with Apple falling 2.7%, Microsoft losing 3% and Amazon off 4.3%.

“One of the other big cautionary points for investors is that the inflation impact of tariffs has yet to show up in the data, which is why we believe this is the calm before the tariff storm, with inflation likely to head more north than south in the coming months,” said Greg Bassuk, CEO at AXS Investments in New York.

The S&P 500 declined 1.97% to end at 5,580.94 points.

The Nasdaq fell 2.70% to 17,322.99 points, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.69% to 41,583.90 points.

Ten of the 11 S&P 500 sector indexes declined, led lower by communication services, down 3.81%, followed by a 3.27% loss in consumer discretionary.

Interest rate futures suggest traders see a 76% likelihood that the Fed will cut interest rates by 25 basis points by its June meeting, according to CME FedWatch.

With Friday’s losses, the S&P 500 is down about 9% from its record-high close on Feb. 19. The Nasdaq is down around 14% from its record-high close on Dec. 16.

“The problem is we don’t know the rules and businesses really struggle with that,” said Bob Doll, chief executive officer of Crossmark Investments.

“Part of the economic weakness we’re experiencing and likely to see more of is a function of individuals and businesses saying, ‘I’m not quite sure what tomorrow’s going to bring, so I’ll just be a little more cautious.'”

An index tracking interest-rate-sensitive banks fell 2.3%.

The CBOE volatility index rose almost 3 points to a one-week high.

CoreWeave’s shares opened nearly 3% below their offer price in the Nvidia-backed artificial intelligence infrastructure company’s Nasdaq debut on Friday. That weak debut could crush hopes of a meaningful recovery in stock market listings, especially as equity markets grapple with tariff-related turmoil.

Trump’s steadfast commitment to a 25% tariff on auto imports, set to take effect next week, weighed on auto stocks for a second day, with General Motors down 1.1% and Ford losing 1.8%.

For the week, the S&P 500 fell 1.5%, the Nasdaq declined 2.6%, and the Dow fell about 1%.

Attention now turns to a fresh round of tariffs the Trump administration is set to unveil on April 2, with Trump recently hinting that these measures might diverge from the straightforward tit-for-tat duties previously pledged.

Shares of Lululemon Athletica plunged 14% after the sportswear maker lowered its annual forecasts, citing unpredictability surrounding tariffs.

Mining companies Harmony Gold and Gold Fields rallied 9.5% and 4.5%, respectively, on higher gold prices related to trade war concerns.

The S&P 500 is on track for its first quarterly decline in six quarters, while the tech-centric Nasdaq is set for its deepest quarterly drop since 2022.

UBS Global Wealth Management lowered its year-end target for the S&P 500 to 6,400 from 6,600.

Wolfspeed slumped 52% a day after the chipmaker appointed a new CEO amid its struggles to improve its financial position.

Declining stocks outnumbered rising ones within the S&P 500 by a 4.5-to-1 ratio.

The S&P 500 posted 10 new highs and 23 new lows; the Nasdaq recorded 35 new highs and 358 new lows.

Volume on U.S. exchanges was relatively light, with 14.3 billion shares traded, compared to an average of 16.2 billion shares over the previous 20 sessions.
summary: Inflation and tariff worries sent shares of Wall Street's most valuable companies sharply lower. © Reuters Consumer spending rebounds less than expected, while price gauge rises March 29, 2025 05:29 J...
title: U.S. stocks tumble as fresh data fuels inflation fear

content:
Japanese company counts on IT business growth to reach fiscal 2025 target

TOKYO — Japan’s NTT Data Group aims to achieve record-high net profit for the first time in three years in fiscal 2025 through expansion and selling assets to a real estate investment trust specializing in data centers, Senior Executive Vice President Kazuhiko Nakayama told Nikkei.

Edited excerpts from the interview follow.

Q: Consolidated net profit for fiscal 2024 is projected to be 137 billion yen, up 2% from the previous year. Are things going as planned?

A: They’re progressing smoothly. In Japan, sales to government agencies and other organizations are doing well, and the DC [data center] business overseas is booming. This is making up for the poor performance of IT systems in Germany, the U.K., Australia and elsewhere.

The weak yen has caused foreign-currency-denominated debt to swell, making interest payment costs a burden, but we have been moving debt to fixed interest rates and refinancing to yen-denominated debt, helping us stay within our plan.

Q: Fiscal 2025 is the final year of your medium-term management plan. What is your path to achieving numerical targets like 4.7 trillion yen in consolidated sales and a 10% consolidated operating profit margin?

A: We are in the process of examining the situation, but we plan to draw up a plan to achieve the targets. For the figures in the medium-term plan, operating profit for fiscal 2025 would need to grow by double digits from the planned figure for fiscal 2024. Excluding such one-time expenses as mergers and acquisitions and restructuring, we need to add more than 100 billion yen, so it’s a very challenging target.

Breaking it down, the expansion of the IT system business will account for about 30 billion yen. This can be achieved if it grows at the same rate as the IT market. Synergy effects with NTT Ltd., the IT infrastructure company that was brought under our umbrella in 2022, are expected to be 30 billion yen.

Through joint proposals with NTT Data’s system development, [IT] orders received in the April-December period of 2024 reached about 160 billion yen, exceeding the amount for all of fiscal 2023 [130 billion yen].

Integration costs for overseas businesses, such as consolidating and closing offices — which are expected to be 30 billion yen in fiscal 2024 — will be reduced by at least 10 billion yen in fiscal 2025. We plan to set up a DC REIT in fiscal 2025. The rest will be covered by asset sales and more.

Q: How much will be sold to the data center REIT?

A: During the April-December period of 2024, we transferred just under 94 billion yen in DC-related assets to assets held for sale. This is an accounting procedure in preparation for the sale of assets. Though it will depend to some extent on future market conditions, we expect to sell at most around that much in assets in fiscal 2025.

We will incorporate DCs that have been established for a relatively long time and have high rack occupancy rates into the REIT, with REIT investors that prefer income gains in mind. Because of international accounting standards, profit from the sales will contribute to earnings starting at the operating profit level. Even after the sales, we can expect them to contribute to revenue through maintenance contracts.

Q: Markets forecast net profit of 183.3 billion yen in fiscal 2025. Net profit has been sluggish in recent years. What are the company’s plans?

A: Since we posted record profit in fiscal 2022 [of 149.9 billion yen], interest-bearing debt from DC investments has increased sharply, and rising interest rates have made interest payments a burden. We expect a financial loss of 81 billion yen for fiscal 2024.

Net profit trends are directly linked to formation of stock prices. We would like to do something about the stagnation of the past few years by expanding operating profit and reducing financial expenses.

Although financial earnings for fiscal 2025 may be 20 billion yen deeper in the red than the current fiscal year’s plan, we will likely be able to achieve our highest profit in three years [after factoring in operating profit].
summary: NTT Data Senior Vice President Kazuhiko Nakayama said the company's plans are "progressing smoothly." (Photo by Kosuke Okamoto) Japanese company counts on IT business growth to reach fiscal 2025 targe...
title: NTT Data eyes record profit by selling data centers: executive

content:
Pet 'humanization' drives world-beating growth; post-pandemic companionship appeal rises

GONGJU, South Korea/KUALA LUMPUR — Over the first half of this century, the number of people living in Asia will see a nearly 1.5-fold increase. But the region hosts another community that is multiplying fast — household pets.

That means a multibillion-dollar business opportunity is knocking for providers of all kinds of pet products and services, from food and health care to tech and tourism, as people across a region — which the United Nations estimates will be home to 5 billion by 2050 — become more affluent and splurge on pets as a source of companionship, spurred in part by the COVID-19 pandemic.

And even in countries like South Korea, where birth rates are alarmingly low, purse strings are being opened for free spending on pets, rather than children, as what experts call the “humanization” of household animals kicks in.

In Gongju, a city just over an hour from Seoul, among those in the market for gourmet treats are 1-year-old golden retriever Lucky, and Dodo, a 6-year-old Doberman. The pair dined out on a recent trip to Dogchelin — a riff on the Michelin guide for restaurants — where they wolfed down a 10,000 won ($7) four-course meal featuring salmon fillet and green beans, as well as pumpkin soup and milk ice cream.

“They eat a lot. Lucky and Dodo eat 50 kilograms of food each per month,” said their owner Park Sun-young, who along with her husband, Lee Jung-yeon, dotes on the pair who are making their second trip to Dogchelin. “We consider all aspects to choose their food: ingredients, nutrition and of course, price.”

Driven by what it sees as the increasing humanization of household animals, Euromonitor International, a data analytics company, expects the Asia-Pacific market for pet food and other products to hit $34.8 billion by 2029, up by a fifth in the space of five years. With a compound annual growth rate of 4% over that period, the Asia-Pacific market will easily outstrip North America’s 2.5% growth and will be nearly double Western Europe’s 2.1%, Euromonitor predicts.

“Growth prospects offered by pet care in Asia-Pacific are not only conducive for incumbents but for new entrants as well,” Sahiba Puri, senior consultant at Euromonitor, told Nikkei Asia.

“Product attributes like innovative formats, health-oriented claims and functional ingredients along with retail availability through channels like pet specialists, marketplaces and direct-to-consumer have enabled startups to gain a foothold in the market.”

Gongju’s Dogchelin is run by Harim Pet Food, part of a South Korean food business known for its chicken, as part of a two-hour tour for pet owners at its factory. Led by its flagship brand The Real, Harim Pet Food’s revenue jumped 15% to around 50 billion won last year, and the company forecasts similar growth this year.

“Our motto is 100% human-grade,” Kim Eun-kyoung, head of the brand management team at the company, told Nikkei. “We don’t want to feed pets food that people cannot eat.”

In Gongju city in South Korea, pets Dodo, left, and Lucky were treated to a four-course gourmet meal at Dogchelin, a restaurant for dogs named after the Michelin food guides. (Photo by Jean Chung)

It’s not all about food, however. There is a range of products and services being developed, from pet clothing to veterinary tech devices and insurance. Even tourism is an area where demand for pet services is rising, and regional businesses are prominent: According to Euromonitor, the leading three pet care players in the Asia-Pacific region by revenue in 2023 were U.S. giant Mars, Japan’s Inaba Petfood Co. and fellow Japanese company Unicharm. The top three globally were Nestle, Mars and Colgate-Palmolive.

LG Uplus, a Seoul-based telecoms company, offered charter flight services for pets and their owners four times last year in cooperation with Jeju Air. The company charged 750,000 won for three seats — two owners and one pet — in the fourth flight in October, from Seoul to Jeju, after three previous sold-out trips.

In countries like South Korea and Vietnam, the trend for “humanization” of pets such as dogs has coincided with a shift among younger consumers away from dog meat dishes that can still be found on menus favored by older people. The trend became more pronounced across the region during the COVID-19 pandemic, industry watchers say, as lockdowns boosted the companionship appeal of household animals.

A growing affinity for pets in India, where Euromonitor forecasts a nearly 60% jump in the pet care market over the 2024-2029 period, took root with remote workers during the pandemic, according to consulting company Redseer.

A dog owner checks a shopping list of premium dog foods during a tour at Harim Pet Food in Gongju, South Korea. The company says its pet food is “100% human-grade.” (Photo by Jean Chung)

“The rise of nuclear families and urbanization has made pets an ideal source of companionship, with individuals increasingly seeking emotional support from animals,” Redseer analyst Amitabh Kumar told Nikkei recently.

Young people have now become the dominant force in pet ownership in Asia, some of whom are opting to raise pets instead of having children.

According to a Goldman Sachs report, the number of cats and dogs in China in 2024 was already comparable to the number of children aged 4 or under. With declining birth rates and increasing pet ownership, the number of pets in China is expected to be nearly twice that of children by 2030. 

“Young people in China today struggle to find the same sense of ambition and optimism as previous generations,” said Starr Liu, a cat owner and founder of Shenzhen-based Petpa, a startup that manufactures AI-powered multi-pet feeders. “With more women choosing not to marry or have children, emotional needs still require an outlet, leading many to turn to pets for companionship and fulfillment.”

“China’s pet culture has evolved rapidly, surpassing that of many Western countries. China’s pet economy began booming around 2015, shifting in just a decade from feeding pets table scraps to basic pet food, then imported brands, and now premium domestic products. Additionally, young Chinese consumers are more willing to embrace smart pet technology,” said Liu.

In Hanoi, tech sector worker Le Bui, owner of three cats, told Nikkei Asia that she thinks the rise of the pet industry is underpinned by changing societal priorities as people in countries like Vietnam become better off.

“More and more people are caring about their mental health. If you are by yourself it’s more fun to have pets,” said Le, 35, who spends around 2.5 million to 3 million Vietnamese dong ($100 to $120) per month on her cats. “It’s nice to have pets waiting on you when you come home from work. It’s also for parents to teach their kids about caring and sharing.”

“In the past, Vietnamese were so poor we only care about feeding our family. But now we also care about our mental health … so this explains why this industry grows quickly. I think it’s also because of our strong economic growth compared to the region.”

Pet humanization in places like Vietnam has also shown up in the way consumers feed their animals, moving from feeding pets table scraps to buying food targeted at animal nutrition. In a 2024 Euromonitor survey, 20% of respondents in the Asia-Pacific region said they feed their pets table scraps on an everyday basis, down from 25% in 2021.

LG Uplus, a Seoul-based telecom company, offered sold-out charter flight services from Seoul to Jeju specially tailored for pets and their owners four times last year in cooperation with Jeju Air. (Photo by Jeju Air)

Vietnam’s pet care market is comparatively small in the region, but is among those tipped by Euromonitor for the strongest growth — just over a third in 2024-2029. At the other end of the scale sits Japan, a very large, highly developed pet care market but one seen growing a meager 0.9% a year over 2024-2029.

Japan has long been known as a center for premium pet goods, from strollers for dogs to Chanel leashes and collars. But it’s also a country where the number of household pets has outstripped the number of children under 14 for decades as its society rapidly ages.

“In general, the performance of the pet care industry is closely tied to the number of households,” Euromonitor consultant Megumi Matsunaga told Nikkei. “The number of households in Japan has been increasing, even as the population declines. This trend is expected to reverse in the early 2030s. … This demographic shift is likely to negatively impact the performance of the pet care industry.”

Demographics and decisions not to have children, for financial or other reasons, play a part in many choices to acquire pets across the region.

In Malaysia, nearly two-thirds of households have pets, according to a study by Global Pets — primarily cats, as dogs are considered “unclean” or impure according to Islam, though some households do still opt for dogs.

And young married couples in their early 30s, like Nicholas Wong and Su Wen, told Nikkei that it is common among their peers to have pets while some are not keen to have children because of affordability issues.

“I think it’s more common. On the one hand, it could be about companionship, and on the other, I think some of my friends who are not keen on kids find it more affordable and less of a lifestyle change,” said Wong, who works as a risk adviser at McKinsey.

Wong and Su Wen adopted two stray cats at first and are currently nursing and fostering two more cats in his condominium unit in Petaling Jaya, a city just half an hour from the center of Kuala Lumpur. 

Wong said cats are much easier to deal with than dogs and are a better fit with his lifestyle. “I’ve had dogs before, but the costs and care are higher for dogs. They eat more, and as they age, they tend to develop more health issues,” said Wong.

Jawahir Abdullah, left, a veterinary doctor for more than a decade, said she has been using AI-driven diagnostics and telemedicine platforms to treat pets in her clinic. (Photo by Norman Goh)

Veterinary services are a significant part of the overall market for pet care, and in some cases also an opening for new technology providers.

At Ohana Veterinary Clinic, located in the upscale residential area of Taman Tun Dr. Ismail in Kuala Lumpur, Jawahir Abdullah, a vet for more than a decade, told Nikkei that she has been using AI-driven diagnostics and telemedicine platforms, such as a blood testing machine that can analyze results and compare them with international data.

“We also use software and applications that can scan pets and provide data like weight and temperature,” she said.

Some vets rely on alternative tech medicine. Jawahir said alternative treatments like laser therapy and natural remedies are on the rise because owners are “scared of the side effects of drugs,” opting for alternatives like turmeric or laser treatments, including Traditional Chinese Veterinary Medicine (TCVM).

While TCVM is not yet formally regulated by Malaysian veterinary authorities, its practices, such as acupuncture, herbal medicine, and food therapy, are increasingly being integrated into some veterinary clinics.

A vet at an animal hospital in Seoul examines a dog X-ray using technology from telecoms operator SK Telecom. Veterinary services are a big part of the overall market for pet care, as well as an opening for new tech providers. (Photo by SK Telecom)

Jawahir reckoned that pet ownership in Malaysia increased by 32% compared with before COVID-19, and the trend has changed significantly in the past decade. Pets can improve the mental health of owners and dogs are very sensitive to emotions, and “they know when their owners are stressed.”

“Yes, it’s very significant compared to my early days. Now, owners want nutrition, specific treatments, and more. They’re willing to spend because they see pets as part of the family,” Jawahir said. She also mentioned that her clients are more educated and saw increased knowledge-seeking behavior on platforms like TikTok and ChatGPT, making it easier to explain to her clients.

“Malaysia is still catching up, but the industry has a lot of potential. More people are treating pets as family members, and they’re willing to spend on their care. However, vets need to upskill, and the industry needs more manpower to keep up with demand,” she said.

Services for pets continue beyond their passing. Cemetery and funeral services are common across parts of Asia, from South Korea and Japan to Malaysia and Vietnam — and can generate hefty bills.

Cats pictured at a pet adoption center in Petaling Jaya, Malaysia. Though comparatively small in Asia, the Malaysian pet care market is expected to grow 30% between 2024 and 2029. (Photo by Norman Goh)

In Hanoi, Le Bui added up the cost of saying farewell to one of her previous pets.

“When my cat Dua (Coconut) died, I put her in a cemetery in Bach Mai district in Hanoi,” she said. “Cremation costs 12 million dong. Burial costs 30 million. They offer full service including worshiping, chanting, the ’49-day ceremony’ and other ceremonies.” 

The 49-day ceremony is an event for the dead in Vietnam where Buddhist monks chant for hours with family members sitting around an altar, followed by big meals.

“For the pet case I think it’s chanting only. It signifies that the deceased has gone to be with Buddha,” Le said.

Additional reporting by Cissy Zhou in Hong Kong and Mai Nguyen in Hanoi.
summary: Nicholas Wong and his partner Su Wen, pictured with three cats at their home just outside Kuala Lumpur, are among Asia's growing legion of pet lovers. Experts say domestic animals have becom...
title: Asia’s pet boom lets food, health care, tech players off leash

content:
Brian Moynihan weighs opportunities in stablecoins as annual spending reaches $4bn

TOKYO — Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan has signaled the institution plans to continue investing aggressively into advanced technology to achieve “responsible growth.”

“Responsible growth is about growing, no excuses,” Moynihan said in a recent interview with Nikkei, referring to the strategy he adopted after becoming chief executive in 2010.

Since taking the post, Moynihan has sold $300 billion in assets and nearly 50 units to lay the groundwork for growth. Bank of America’s net profit increased for the first time in three years last year.

Technology lies at the heart of this push. The bank put $4 billion into technology initiatives last year, double the figure from 10 years earlier.

If customers use digital technology every day in other parts of their lives, “we have to have the capabilities for them to do that [in banking] or somebody will take that customer away,” Moynihan said.

Bank of America introduced an artificial-intelligence-powered chatbot, “Erica,” ahead of rivals in 2018, with total interactions with customers reaching 2.5 billion as of the end of last year. Zelle, its electronic money transferring service, has gained 23.7 million users since launching in 2017.

The goal is to make money for shareholders and increase “teammate delight and satisfaction” at the same time, Moynihan said. Bank of America has 35,000 coders in-house and another 15,000 outside. It was granted the most patents of any U.S. financial institution in 2023.

The investments are paying off. Linking Erica to the CashPro corporate banking platform has helped increase users for the latter. Over $1 trillion in transfers were approved on CashPro last year.

Moynihan also expressed an interest in stablecoins, a type of cryptocurrency pegged to assets like currency or gold. The Trump administration is planning to create a legal framework for dollar-backed stablecoins.

“We have a bunch of blockchain patents already” and plan to use them once there is a legal framework established, Moynihan said.

Regarding the rapidly increasing private credit market, he said that “banking regulators… have to be careful because, whether it’s mortgage loans or commercial loans or whatever, the more outside the system, you have to worry whether you can actually see it and understand it and make sure leverage and other” things are being monitored.

Regarding collaborating with private credit funds, he said, “We work with a lot of the companies now to find assets for them, distribute for them, to finance those assets and we have lots of great clients. So, I’m not sure we’ll ever do anything that exclusive to anybody who we work with a lot.”

When asked about the governance changes taking place in Japan, he said he hears “from the CEOs I’ve met with, and they’re embracing the reforms and think that they’re going to be good and help them be more competitive and do more things on a global basis.”

He added that Bank of America’s business can help them “think through their strategies and executing those strategies.”
summary: Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan advocates for "responsible growth." (Photo by Satoko Kawasaki) Brian Moynihan weighs opportunities in stablecoins as annual spending reaches $4bn SHIKO UEDA Mar...
title: Bank of America CEO doubles down on tech investments for growth

content:
Group aims to offer business-to-business services in fast-growing market

TOKYO — Leading Japanese ground delivery provider Yamato Holdings aims to triple annual overseas revenue within the next few years and sees India as its top priority for growth.

“We’ll expand the scope of our business while keeping our eye out for M&A deals,” President Yutaka Nagao told Nikkei.

“It’s a country with such growth potential,” Nagao said of India. “It would be a waste to try to expand there on our own.”

Yamato has “found partners with whom we’re able to hold various discussions,” Nagao said.

“We’ll make up-front investments, including setting up multiple warehouses, and combine them with the transportation networks” built by Indian companies, he said.

Yamato expects roughly 150 billion yen ($1 billion) in overseas sales for the fiscal year ending Monday.

The company will shift its growth focus to corporate business, which covers a wide range of logistics operations, such as inventory management and distribution processing for industries like autos and electronics. Yamato aims to grow revenue in Asia and the U.S.

Yamato Holdings President Yutaka Nagao speaks with Nikkei on March 27 in Tokyo. (Photo by Kotaro Igarashi)

India is expected to become the world’s third-largest economy in 2027. The country’s freight and logistics market will reach $545.6 billion in 2030, according to Mordor Intelligence — up more than 50% from the company’s 2025 forecast.

Yamato will raise funds for acquisitions by reviewing assets and reducing cross-shareholdings. The group completed the sale of Tokyo headquarters buildings Friday, switching to a leaseback agreement. Yamato is considering switching to lease contracts for a portion of its delivery vehicles and distribution centers.

Consumers account for 60% or so of the parcels that Yamato handles. Japan’s declining population is pushing the company to grow its business-to-business services.

Meanwhile, the number of collection and delivery centers serving consumers around Japan will be reduced by roughly 40% from the current 2,800 or so. The centers will be consolidated into 1,800 locations by the end of fiscal 2026.

The company’s parcel delivery service has struggled amid a downturn in consumer spending, though the business has shown signs of recovering. In the October-December period of 2024, Yamato’s consolidated operating profit rose 9% to mark its first year-on-year growth in eight quarters.

But Yamato still faces pressure from a trucking-sector labor shortage under new overtime rules and is being squeezed by high fuel prices. To secure enough personnel, “we need price pass-throughs in line with inflation,” Nagao said.

Yamato looks to renegotiate freight prices with large corporations that have been given greatly discounted rates.

“We’ll also upgrade our sales capabilities so that [customers] understand that the prices are fair,” Nagao said.
summary: Yamato Holdings will consolidate its domestic network of collection and delivery centers. (Photo by Kai Ishizaki) Group aims to offer business-to-business services in fast-growing market KAI ISHIZAKI ...
title: Japan delivery king Yamato looks to India, M&A to triple overseas sales

content:
Southeast Asia adapts as outbound Chinese travel remains below pre-pandemic levels

David Mann is chief economist for the Asia-Pacific, Middle East and Africa at Mastercard.

Vietnam is aiming for Thailand’s crown as Southeast Asia’s top international tourist destination. And Indian visitors may help it get there.

Thailand still welcomes the most tourists of any Southeast Asian nation, with 35.5 million arrivals in 2024. But Vietnam is the region’s fastest-growing market; its 17.5 million arrivals last year representing an impressive 40% year-over-year increase. Vietnam is targeting 23 million tourists in 2025, a 28% climb from 2019’s figure and a 31% rise year over year.

In Vietnam and across Southeast Asia, the makeup of tourists is changing. With China’s overall outbound international travel still around 80% of its 2019 peak and its GDP growth slowing, another source market is rising to fill the gap: India, where outbound international flight capacity has already surged to 110% of the 2019 level.

For Thailand, this new source of tourists means a reprieve from the economic blow of reduced Chinese travel. For other parts of Southeast Asia, where Chinese travel is surging alongside Indian travel, it represents a double-shot of economic input.

But in all these places, businesses and the public are going to need to get used to a new mix of tourists — and the new spending patterns that go with it.

China’s travel rebound is playing out differently across Southeast Asia, but flight capacity between China and the region is still only 77% of what it was in 2019. Thailand was once China’s most popular overseas destination, but that title belongs to Japan now.

The big Buddha statues are seen at Wat Phra That Pha Sorn Kaew temple, Khao Kho district, Phetchabun province, Thailand, in December 2024.   © Reuters

China’s economic expansion has slowed, with real GDP growth coming in at 5% in 2024 compared to pre-pandemic levels of 6% or higher. Its increasingly well-traveled outbound tourists are also looking for new adventures.

Thailand is targeting 40 million tourists in 2025, up from 35.5 million in 2024. If it can achieve this, it will top 2019’s 39 million arrivals for the first time since the pandemic. But it must do so with less help from Chinese visitors, who in 2019 made up 28% of tourist arrivals but in 2024 accounted for 18.9%. Flight capacity between mainland China and Thailand remains 35% lower than in 2019, suggesting arrivals won’t rise sharply soon.

To encourage mutual tourism, China entered reciprocal visa-free travel agreements with Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore in 2023 and early 2024. Last year, Malaysia’s arrivals from China reached 105% of 2019’s level while Singapore’s were at 85%, with Chinese people representing the largest and highest-spending segment.

Thailand’s arrivals from China were just 61% of the 2019 level, albeit with more overall visitors than its neighbors: 6.73 million, compared with 3.29 for Malaysia and 3.08 for Singapore.

India is rising to challenge China as Southeast Asia’s single-largest source market. New flights and easier visas have ushered in huge increases in Indian arrivals to Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam, with India’s strong economic growth (6.4% projected in the 2024-2025 financial year) offering a tailwind.

Indians are expected to shell out around $120 billion annually on outbound tourism by 2035, according to Capital Economics, which would make them the fourth-biggest spenders globally — behind the U.S., China and Germany.

Thailand and Malaysia have introduced visa-free arrivals for Indian visitors following the pandemic and have seen arrivals from the subcontinent rise from 2019 by 7% and 54%, respectively. Bangkok has overtaken Dubai as the most popular city destination for Indian travelers.

The most dramatic increase has been in Vietnam, where new nonstop routes have been introduced since 2022, leading to a 363% increase in Indian arrivals in 2024 from 2019.

Chinese arrivals in Vietnam, by comparison, were only 65% of their 2019 level. But Vietnam’s meteoric rise continues, driven by India and a growing mix of other international arrivals led by South Korea.

A slowing economy isn’t the only contributor to Chinese tourists’ changing travel. Mastercard’s data shows they are increasingly interested in new experiences and destinations. We see 9.5% of outbound tourism spend from Chinese travelers on experiences and nightlife. Indians, meanwhile, tend spend more on shopping.

Many Chinese travelers have already been to Southeast Asia and are keen to go further afield. Evidencing this, 2024 traffic on China-Egypt and China-Central Asia routes was more than double that of 2019.

Many Indian travelers may be taking their first international trip as members of the country’s growing middle class. Southeast Asia represents an easy first foray. Looser visa requirements are significant: The Indian passport offers visa-free entry to 56 places worldwide, according to the Henley Passport Index. China’s offers 83.

For first-time travelers, ease, safety and cultural sensitivity are paramount. Many Indians follow specialized diets and the availability of appropriate food ranks high among their travel concerns. Like all tourists, they also want to use payment methods they already understand and feel confident in their physical and financial safety.

Thailand, which has historically welcomed Indian tourists, has for years offered Indian food at its major tourist destinations. Malaysia, home to a large Indian population, has a built-in ability to welcome these new arrivals. Vietnam is working to ensure its new tourists can eat and shop in the style and at the price point they seek.

The changing face of tourism in Southeast Asia should help diversify the tourist trade, lending stability to this vital economic pillar. Don’t expect Chinese characters to disappear from menus and hotel lobbies — but look for more Devanagari text alongside them.
summary: Vietnam's meteoric tourism rise continues, driven by India and a growing mix of other international arrivals led by South Korea. Southeast Asia adapts as outbound Chinese travel remains below pre-pand...
title: With India’s help, Vietnam challenges for Thailand’s tourism crown

content:
Chinese smartphone maker balances core ops with meteoric growth in EVs

GUANGZHOU — Xiaomi’s SU7 electric vehicle has overtaken the Tesla Model 3 in Chinese sales a year after its release, turning the company into a rising star in EVs even as it continues to log solid growth in its mainstay smartphone business.

Earlier in March, Samsung Electronics Chairman Lee Jae-yong met with Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun at the latter’s EV factory in Beijing. Local media reported that Samsung, Xiaomi’s major rival on smartphones, was exploring cooperation with the Chinese company as it expands its footprint in electric vehicles.

Xiaomi is building a second EV plant close by. It also plans to launch a sport utility vehicle this year toward the goal of more than doubling overall deliveries from 2024 to 350,000 units.

Around 186,000 SU7s have been sold in China since April 2024, outpacing the Tesla Model 3, according to a Chinese auto data provider. Though the basic SU7 starts at 215,900 yuan ($29,700) to the Model 3’s 235,500 yuan, it has a longer driving range, at 700 kilometers to 634 km, as well as a faster acceleration time from zero to 100 kph, at 5.28 seconds to 6.1 seconds.
